comments.commentBody: We need to get access to Trump's Tax records without any delay (by Congressional order, Court order) to figure out if the current President had been bought over by the Russians. The plausible Trump-Puttin dynamics could only be unraveled if we could get these documents.
If Sessions steps down now, will he be able to avoid prosecution later on?
Well Flynn resigning and his boss accepting before his seat was even warm,...doesn't help allay suspicions.
Maybe we can clear this up with 3 investigative committees, 8 hearings and and 11 hours of testimony (each) from Trump, Pence and Sessions.

replies.commentBody: Excuse me!  There's plenty of hard evidence, i.e. hacking and releasing the Democrats campaign emails.  Flynn being kicked out for lying about secret talks with Russian operatives during the campaign... and now Sessions lying under oath about the same.

Excuse me!  There's plenty of hard evidence, i.e. hacking and releasing the Democrats campaign emails.  Flynn being kicked out for lying about secret talks with Russian operatives during the campaign... and now Sessions lying under oath about the same.

comments.commentBody: Although my heart and mind are with the democratic party I believe that some of its members and some members of the intelligence community need to see a psychologist to determine the origin and fervor of their anti-Russian feelings. As for now I am with  John Mearsheimer 's dictum that there is no hard evidence for the alleged Russian attack on the American democracy. Similar fears that the Russians were undermining the democratic fabric in Germany were put to rest a short while ago by the BND, the national intelligence service of Germany, who had researched for one year in vain to find any clues for such an interference.
The FBI has jurisdiction, not the President.

Maybe Trump's family should start a global fund raising effort to consolidate worldwide relief aid that could give such donors & recipients the possibility of access to the White House. . .and have the older sons of the President to give speeches for hundred of thousands of dollars for each speech to those donors.  Of course, this wouldn't be considered unethical.

Trump's best defense is to just declassify the details of everything. Just stating that there were "contacts" and "connections" without context allows the mind to spin whatever cynical fantasies it wants to fill in information vacuum. The FBI has already investigated the domestic side and found nothing illegal or improper from the Trump campaign. And the CIA has already investigated the foreign side and also found no evidence of collusion. Trump was the hapless beneficiary of Clinton's long career of making enemies. The administration should release the raw material FBI and CIA drew these conclusions from and quash the innuendo once and for all.

Technology is allowing and making it easier for both individuals and governments to influence elections of other countries around the world.  Perhaps this is the beginning of what technology will eventually create for the future -- a one government system for the world.
comments.userDisplayName: S a m u e l

comments.commentBody: If there's an innocent explanation for all of this, I'd like to hear it, because I certainly can't imagine what it might be.
If there was reasonable suspicion or probable cause the FBI has jurisdiction, not the President.

The Trump Administration could not be conducting itself in more of a suspicious manner if they tried. Every denial or attempt to downplay the importance of these stories is a red flag to anyone with an ounce of investigative curiosity.
If nothing untoward occurred during those two meetings, why did he lie under oath during the Congressional hearing that he'd had no contact with the Russian ambassador?

I would have assumed that those who are in government or opposition parties are perfectly free to communicate with diplomats from any country.  In fact, if they are not communicating, then they are not doing their jobs.  This would be especially necessary if there were issues between their own country and that of the diplomat's.   It does not surprise me that no attempt at reconciliation has been made when it comes to Russia.  There are probably diplomats from other country that the U.S. just does not bother to speak to, except at the level of State where highly-publicized meetings can be spun to some effect.    Such failure to communicate diplomatically we can perhaps take as an indication that the U.S. will go to war with said countries regardless of what possible reconciliations can be reached.   I do recognize that it is much easier and less time-consuming to speak only to one's 'friends,' but that is not responsible governance.

A large part of the problem is the belief held by some not insignificant few that anything that one does to make oneself wealthier is "OK". Among that crowd (and they own the Republicans) the concept of selling the "General Welfare" of the American people for more wealth has no derogatory meaning. Quite the contrary; they believe that America and her people exist solely for the purpose of their own further enrichment. Understand that "that crowd" doesn't just influence this Administration; rather, this Administration is representative of "that crowd".

To properly analyze and predict "that crowd", one must discard all assumptions of "boundaries" on behavior emplaced by concepts such as morality, honesty, loyalty, honor, etc., to include the very concept that one unconsciously assumes is a prerequisite for national leadership: patriotism.

Mr. Sessions' contacts with representatives from any foreign government is no more significant than John McCain going to Syria to meet with Assad.  He was head of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.  Of course he would have meetings with foreign representatives.  Quit publishing this misleading, speculative nonsense until you have verifiable proof of wrong-doing.

There is just way too much smoke here for Congress to ignore the underlying fire.  This situation threatens the fundamentals of our democratic system, and should be dealt with quickly and forcefully.  Those Republicans who still have their integrity intact need to step forward.
Obviously, these officials who took it upon themselves to release classified information should be prosecuted and jailed

What a mess..... I have no doubt that Republicans will focus on President Obama's efforts to preserve intelligence ABOVE any concern about what the evidence shows.

I always knew that House and Senate Republicans were shameless hypocrites.....I had no idea that they would so fully demonstrate it this early in the new administration!
I forgot to add that I believe this lie under oath during his confirmation hearing makes his subsequent confirmation which is based on the answers he gave, invalid.

The GOP put countless man hours and dollars into the Benghazi hearings. And when they didn't find the answer they were looking for (that it was Clinton's fault), they held more hearings. Logic would suggest that the faintest suggestion of impeachable activity would spark immediate and incessant hearings. Unfortunately, pragmatism suggests far more strongly that they are partisan hacks, who will nail a strong democrat for jaywalking while allowing a feckless republican to commit treason. Permitting treason IS treason. Open, bipartisan investigation is the only satisfactory course.

Indeed, as another commenter says, this is patriotism, and I'm sure that all (NOT) Republicans will eventually applaud these fine Americans for doing the Hansel & Gretl thing with our nation's security.
